headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greetings and welcome to the Leggett & Platt Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, David DeSonier, Vice President, Strategy and Investor Relations for Leggett & Platt. Thank you, Mr. DeSonier
componenttext:
Greetings and welcome to the Leggett & Platt Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, David DeSonier, Vice President, Strategy and Investor Relations for Leggett & Platt. 
Thank you, Mr. DeSonier, you may begin.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for taking part in Leggett & Platt's fourth quarter conference call. I'm Dave DeSonier. And with me today are the following: Dave Haffner, our CEO and President; Karl Glassman, our Chief Operating Officer; Matt Flanigan, our CF
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for taking part in Leggett & Platt's fourth quarter conference call. I'm Dave DeSonier. And with me today are the following: Dave Haffner, our CEO and President; Karl Glassman, our Chief Operating Officer; Matt Flanigan, our CFO; and Susan McCoy, our Director of Investor Relations. The agenda for the call this morning is as follows: Dave Haffner will start with the summary of the major statements we made in yesterday's press release; Karl will provide operating highlights; Dave will then address our outlook for 2011; and finally, the group will answer any questions you have.
I'll mention to you that during the Q&A, Dave Haffner will direct the questions. We're all located in different sites today due to the weather. We have about 20 inches of snow and many of us are still at home trying to dig out of our neighborhood. 
This conference is being recorded for Leggett & Platt and is a copyrighted material. This call may not be transcribed, recorded or broadcast without our express permission. A replay is available from the IR portion of Leggett's website. 
We posted to the IR portion of the website a set of PowerPoint slides that contain summary financial information. Those slides supplement the information we discuss on this call, including non-GAAP reconciliations. I need to remind you that remarks today concerning future expectations, events, objectives, strategies, trends or results constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results or events may differ materially due to a number of risks and uncertainties, and the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise these statements. For a summary of these risk factors and additional information, please refer to yesterday's press release and the section in our 10-K entitled forward-looking statements. 
I'll now turn the call over to Dave Haffner.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning from sunny Missouri, and thank you for participating in our call. Yesterday, we reported fourth quarter and full year results.For the quarter, sales increased 4% compared to the prior year primarily reflecting growth in unit volumes in the
componenttext:
Good morning from sunny Missouri, and thank you for participating in our call. Yesterday, we reported fourth quarter and full year results.
For the quarter, sales increased 4% compared to the prior year primarily reflecting growth in unit volumes in the Specialized Products and Industrial Materials segments. Earnings per share for the quarter were $0.21 versus $0.26 for the same quarter last year. The earnings benefit from higher unit volumes and a lower effective tax rate were offset by a net change in LIFO impact and higher raw material costs.
In the fourth quarter of 2009, we recognized a LIFO benefit of $15 million. As anticipated, that benefit did not recur this year. Instead, in the fourth quarter of 2010, we incurred LIFO expense of $5 million for a year-over-year net change of $20 million.
In late 2010, steel costs began increasing again. These increases along with higher than anticipated LIFO expense led to 150 to 200 basis points of margin compression in the fourth quarter. We have announced price increases in our major steel consuming businesses to recover the higher costs. These increases vary in magnitude depending upon the product category and are being implemented during the first quarter of 2011.
Because of the lag in cost recovery, our first quarter margins will likely be under pressure, but we expect margins to normalize by the second quarter. 
For the full year 2010, we're pleased with the improvements we posted. In both sales and earnings per share, we achieved full year results at or above the high end of guidance issued at the start of the year. Sales grew 10% to $3.36 billion. 
Demand improved in many of our markets during the year. The automotive and office furniture markets experienced significant growth from very depressed demand levels in 2009. Retail fixturing demand was also reasonably strong. Our residential bedding and furniture markets started 2010 strong but weakened in the last half of the year as consumer spending on larger ticket items slowed.
Activities completed over the past few years including the divestiture of businesses under our strategic plan, closure of certain underperforming and underutilized facilities, elimination of sales with unacceptable margins and other cost reduction initiatives improved our cost position and enabled earnings to benefit notably from the higher volume. 
Full year earnings increased to $1.15 per share, which is a 64% improvement versus the $0.70 per share reported in 2009.
During 2010, we completed the sale of the seventh and final divestiture identified as a part of our strategic realignment. The seven divestitures collectively generated $433 million of after-tax cash proceeds over the past three years, exceeding their original $400 million goal. 
Our focus on optimizing returns was reflected throughout 2010 in part through the low level of working capital that was maintained as sales began to recover. We ended the year with working capital at 14.1% of annualized sales.
For the year, we generated operating cash of $363 million, which significantly exceeded the $223 million required to fund capital expenditures and dividends. 
In August, we raised the quarterly dividend to $0.27 per share and extended to 39 years our record of consecutive annual dividend increases. At yesterday's closing price of $22.96, the current dividend yield is 4.7%. As planned, much of the excess operating cash was used to repurchase 6.2 million shares of our stock during 2010.
Our financial profile remains strong. We ended 2010 with net debt to net capital at 23.3%, well below our long-term targeted range of 30% to 40%, no significant fixed term debt maturing until 2013 and over $500 million available under our existing bank facility. We continue to assess our overall performance by comparing our Total Shareholder Return on a rolling three-year basis to that of peer companies. We target TSR in the top 1/3 of the S&P 500 over the long term, which we believe will require an average TSR of 12% to 15% per year. For the three years ended December 31 of 2010, we generated TSR of 16% per year on average, which ranks among the top 8% of the companies in the S&P 500 Index.
And with those comments, I'll turn the call over to Karl Glassman, who will provide some operating highlights. Karl?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave. Good morning. In my comments, I will discuss a few segment highlights. You will find segment details on yesterday's press release and in the slide presentation on our website. As Dave mentioned, our residential bedding and furniture marke
componenttext:
Thank you, Dave. Good morning. In my comments, I will discuss a few segment highlights. You will find segment details on yesterday's press release and in the slide presentation on our website. As Dave mentioned, our residential bedding and furniture markets started 2010 strong but weakened in the last half of the year as consumer spending on larger ticket items slowed.
Fourth quarter sales in the Residential Furnishings segment decreased slightly versus the prior year. Steel-related price inflation from price increases implemented earlier in 2010 was more than offset by unit volume declines in several key businesses.
In our U.S. spring business, innerspring unit volumes decreased 5% in the fourth quarter and box spring units were flat. Unit volumes also declined versus the prior year in our international spring, fabric converting and carpet underlay businesses. 
In our furniture hardware business, the unit volume increased slightly in the fourth quarter. The majority of the full year revenue growth that we experienced in the Residential Furnishings segment is attributable to our furniture components business. This growth is primarily due to market share gains, a well-established international presence and ongoing strength in motion upholstery as consumers continue to favor seating with added functionality and comfort.
Lower unit volumes and higher raw material costs led to a decrease in the segment's fourth quarter EBIT and EBIT margins versus the prior year. We have recently announced price increases in our major steel consuming businesses, including bedding and furniture components, to recover the higher raw material cost. The selling price increases vary by product line ranging from approximately 8% in bedding components to 12% in furniture hardware. We have also announced price increases in our fabric converting and carpet underlay businesses to recover recent inflation in the cost of fabrics and foam scrap. All of the announced selling price increases will be implemented during the first quarter of 2011. 
Current demand in our residential end markets remains well below historical levels. This presents a notable opportunity for both sales and earnings growth over the next few years as those markets recover.
We believe our residential end markets have stabilized and while recovery may continue to be choppy, we are expecting modest overall demand improvements in these markets during 2011.
In the Commercial Fixturing & Components segment, fourth quarter sales grew slightly. We continue to see convincing signs of improvement in the office furniture industry. Fourth quarter sales in our office components business grew approximately 20%, reflecting both market recovery and new programs that we have been awarded. This was the third consecutive quarter that we experienced strong growth in this business.
Sales in our fixture and display business decreased approximately 10% during the fourth quarter versus fourth quarter of 2009. Our prior year comps were difficult due to a high level of late year activity in 2009 by some of our large customers.
For the full year 2010, sales in our store fixtures  and display business grew approximately 5%. Seasonality of this business changed in 2010, with  volume in the first three quarters of the year roughly proportional as retailers increased remodeling activity and reduced new store construction. We expect similar seasonality in 2011. 
EBIT and EBIT margins in the Commercial Fixturing & Components segment decreased versus fourth quarter of 2009. The benefit from sales growth in office components was offset by restructuring-related costs associated with the closure of a wood store fixtures operation. 
Fourth quarter sales in our Industrial Materials segment increased 8%. Growth from higher unit volumes and steel-related price inflation was partially offset by a small divestiture. EBIT and EBIT margins decreased versus fourth quarter of 2009 as higher unit volumes were offset by the absence of EBIT associated with a small divestiture and lower metal margins in the steel industry that reduced the profitability of our steel rod mill. Price increases have recently been announced and implemented in our rod and wire drawing operations in response to the escalation in steel scrap cost. 
In the Specialized Products segment, we posted 17% sales growth in the fourth quarter from continued strength in global automotive demand. We also experienced sales growth in commercial vehicle products during the quarter. Automotive industry forecasts continue to anticipate meaningful global production growth in 2011.
With those comments, I'll turn the call back over to Dave.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karl. Over the last three years, we significantly reduced our fixed cost structure but have retained spare production capacity so that we can accommodate additional sales without the need for large capital investments. As a result, we have mean
componenttext:
Thank you, Karl. Over the last three years, we significantly reduced our fixed cost structure but have retained spare production capacity so that we can accommodate additional sales without the need for large capital investments. As a result, we have meaningful operating leverage that should benefit earnings as sales increase. 
For 2011, we expect sales of approximately $3.4 billion to $3.6 billion, reflecting our belief that the economy will continue to improve modestly. Based on this sales expectation and considering other uncertainties including inflation and steel costs, we project 2011 earnings to be between $1.20 and $1.40 per share.
Cash from operations should exceed $300 million again in 2011. Capital expenditures are expected to be about $85 million, and dividend payments should approximate $155 million.
For the full year, we anticipate purchasing up to 10 million shares of our stock and issuing approximately 3 million shares. We have a standing authorization from the board to repurchase up to 10 million shares each year, but we have no specific repurchase commitment or timetable associated with that authorization.
While challenges continue in certain areas of our business, we are addressing those. We are pleased with many of the business units and their continued progress. We would like to extend our sincere appreciation to our customers for their ongoing support. We remain committed to working together with you for our mutual long-term prosperity. We would also like to thank our employee partners, the men and women whose hard work has contributed to the past year's progress and helped position Leggett for long-term success.
And with those comments, I'll turn the call back over to Dave DeSonier. Dave?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: That concludes our prepared remarks. We thank you for your attention and we will be glad to answer your questions. In order to allow everyone an opportunity to participate, we request that you ask your single best question and then voluntarily yield  to t
componenttext:
That concludes our prepared remarks. We thank you for your attention and we will be glad to answer your questions. In order to allow everyone an opportunity to participate, we request that you ask your single best question and then voluntarily yield  to the next participant. If you additional questions, please re-enter the queue and we'll answer all the questions you have. 
Diego, we are ready to begin the Q&A.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from John Baugh with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from John Baugh with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: There was, if I'm not mistaken, no guidance for Q1. Is that just because with the LIFO being so wild it's really not worth focusing on and it will smooth out for the rest of the year or is there some other reason?
componenttext: There was, if I'm not mistaken, no guidance for Q1. Is that just because with the LIFO being so wild it's really not worth focusing on and it will smooth out for the rest of the year or is there some other reason?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, this is Dave. We didn't give guidance for the quarter because a couple of years ago, we chose to go to annual guidance. So there was never an intention to give guidance for the quarter.
componenttext: John, this is Dave. We didn't give guidance for the quarter because a couple of years ago, we chose to go to annual guidance. So there was never an intention to give guidance for the quarter.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And how do we think about the comment that there will be margin pressure related to the timing of the steel versus getting the pricing?
componenttext: And how do we think about the comment that there will be margin pressure related to the timing of the steel versus getting the pricing?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're in one of those periods, one of those temporary, what I call lag periods, where our cost of raw materials have come up faster than we had anticipated. And we can't, overnight, give price increases to our customers. I guess, in theory we could becaus
componenttext: We're in one of those periods, one of those temporary, what I call lag periods, where our cost of raw materials have come up faster than we had anticipated. And we can't, overnight, give price increases to our customers. I guess, in theory we could because of the pricing position that we have, but that's not ever been our history. So we give our customers adequate notice, allow them to accommodate for their various repricing end markets. So, John, it's likely that we will see margin compression in this first quarter, but we took that into consideration for the annual guidance. Karl, you want to add anything to that?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I would agree with that. The other thing, John, you remember is that we're up against some pretty difficult comps at least in the first half. So we're trying to deal with that. At the same time that our customers, if you heard much of this at the Las
componenttext: No, I would agree with that. The other thing, John, you remember is that we're up against some pretty difficult comps at least in the first half. So we're trying to deal with that. At the same time that our customers, if you heard much of this at the Las Vegas market last week, our customers are very, very optimistic about the full year but have some near-term concerns as it relates to weather. This week certainly isn't helping much of the country. And then the fact that the income tax refunds are delayed anywhere from two to four weeks. And in the residential furnishings part of our business, there's an element at price points that is very sensitive to the receipt of those refunds. So that may delay some purchasing ability into the latter part of the first quarter. But the significant issue truly is this lag of recovering raw material inflation magnified by the fact that we don't know that we've topped out on steel pricing. So the scrap inflation certainly was significant in December and January. We think that there may be a continuation of that which we've warned our customers that the increases that we've announced to date may in fact not be the last. So we're fearful of that type of inflationary run again.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Number one, on the 5% unit decline in innerspring in Q4, could you comment on the customer you lost earlier in the year then regained? What influence that had on the number? And then relate that number to what you think the industry did. And then secondly
componenttext: Number one, on the 5% unit decline in innerspring in Q4, could you comment on the customer you lost earlier in the year then regained? What influence that had on the number? And then relate that number to what you think the industry did. And then secondly, is Sealy's new launch of Posturepedic -- I know you are in vertical with them on a lot of their innerspring business. But does that influence your business with them in any particular way?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Karl, go ahead.
componenttext: Karl, go ahead.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: As we spoke on the third quarter call that we had lost temporarily a little bit of innerspring business to some low pricing that was coming out of Europe at that time. And it was due to the fact that the U.S. steel inflation in the early half of last year
componenttext: As we spoke on the third quarter call that we had lost temporarily a little bit of innerspring business to some low pricing that was coming out of Europe at that time. And it was due to the fact that the U.S. steel inflation in the early half of last year just came earlier than the inflation in Europe, magnified by a very low currency euro-dollar exchange rate. We have regained much of that business as we speak, but John's point is valid. And the fourth quarter demand of U.S. innerspring units was impacted; the units were down from a trend standpoint in October about 6%. November was worse, about 8% off. But those of you that look at the ISPA statistics will remember that the ISPA report for November was particularly soft. And then in December, we had recovered to the point that we were about flat. As we speak today, January was flat through the first three shipping weeks. Last week, we were off about 15%. We believe most of that was weather related. So we've regained most of that business as it relates to the industry, our box springs, as we commented, in the fourth quarter were flat. We believe that our box spring sell-through data is more tightly correlated to industry demand than any other statistic that we see, including the ISPA numbers. They also correlate to some reports from some publicly held companies previous to ours. So we think the industry was flattish 4Q. We think we've recovered the vast majority of that lost volume. Box springs, by the way, through the first three shipping weeks of January were up about 1%. So you can see that connectivity between innerspring and box spring sell-through is narrowed to its normal point. As it relates to Sealy, Sealy did have a relaunch of the Posturepedic line, first time in three years. And we are backwardly integrated with Sealy from the standpoint that all of their box springs are ours, and about 2/3 of their wire are ours. So to the degree that they do experience some success in that line, we'll benefit from that. Also at the Las Vegas market, Serta introduced the new Perfect Sleeper offering and did a fantastic job of that introduction also; 100% of that componentry is ours and that product is positioned at some real velocity price points. So good value for the consumer in both those manufacturers' offerings. We expect that the retailers will promote heavily both off the introduction of those new lines and expect some really good things as the year progresses.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Budd Bugatch with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Budd Bugatch with Raymond James.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Share repurchases look like you assumed an acceleration from about $6 million, I think this year, up to $10 million in 2011. Can you talk a little bit about your view on that?
componenttext: Share repurchases look like you assumed an acceleration from about $6 million, I think this year, up to $10 million in 2011. Can you talk a little bit about your view on that?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Budd, this is Dave. And, Matt or Karl, if you want chime in, please do so. But we still see our shares as a pretty compelling opportunity to invest our shareholders' money. The reason we've said up to $10 million, which is our authorization, and said that
componenttext: Budd, this is Dave. And, Matt or Karl, if you want chime in, please do so. But we still see our shares as a pretty compelling opportunity to invest our shareholders' money. The reason we've said up to $10 million, which is our authorization, and said that we don't have any defined plan, be it accelerated or other defined plan, is that we're hoping that we'll get an opportunity to spend some money this year on some good acquisitions. And so the timing of those share repurchases will be maybe a little less definable than we've had in the past. And yet we feel good about that investment and think that the authorization is one that will probably take full or near full advantage of.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Secondly, you also indicated I think $85 million in capital expenditures this year versus I think you spent $68 million last; what's the acceleration represent?
componenttext: Secondly, you also indicated I think $85 million in capital expenditures this year versus I think you spent $68 million last; what's the acceleration represent?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Budd, what we're seeing is some larger projects. We are in the process of building an addition to our spring plant in Croatia. It's a low-cost facility that services Europe. So we'll incur some monies there in 1Q. Also we're in the process of doing some r
componenttext: Budd, what we're seeing is some larger projects. We are in the process of building an addition to our spring plant in Croatia. It's a low-cost facility that services Europe. So we'll incur some monies there in 1Q. Also we're in the process of doing some retrofits to the Sterling Steel mill. We will keep our people safe there. And as you remember that we purchased that asset out of bankruptcy in 2002. It has continual capital needs. So as you note, the capital spending forecast is up slightly, still significantly below depreciation and amortization. And that is just a sign that there are some particular specific projects that are reasonably large and have their own imputed returns that are certainly satisfactory or Dave wouldn't have let me go wild.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, and also just because we put it into our forecast doesn't mean that we have to spend it. As you know, Budd, we will spend what we feel we need to spend to protect the shareholders and our employees.
componenttext: Yes, and also just because we put it into our forecast doesn't mean that we have to spend it. As you know, Budd, we will spend what we feel we need to spend to protect the shareholders and our employees.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: But there's not any built-in expansion other than the Croatian expansion in the forecast of CapEx?
componenttext: But there's not any built-in expansion other than the Croatian expansion in the forecast of CapEx?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, no production expansion per se. That's correct.
componenttext: Yes, no production expansion per se. That's correct.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Couple of years ago, we talked about getting the $2 a share, talked about getting the 50% or so dividend to payout ratio. I think we're supposed to, or I thought that we were going to end this year with an operating margin exit of about 10%. How delayed a
componenttext: Couple of years ago, we talked about getting the $2 a share, talked about getting the 50% or so dividend to payout ratio. I think we're supposed to, or I thought that we were going to end this year with an operating margin exit of about 10%. How delayed are we in that now? And what do you do to power your way through the ties to the economy that Leggett has and has historically had to kind of get beyond the shackles of where you've been in terms of earnings performance over the last couple of years?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Budd, we still -- you've seen some of the models that we've put together. We still feel comfortable that we'll get to that $2 per share earnings. It's going to take top line. Don't know exactly, is it 2012 now that we get there? Don't really know. Bu
componenttext: Yes, Budd, we still -- you've seen some of the models that we've put together. We still feel comfortable that we'll get to that $2 per share earnings. It's going to take top line. Don't know exactly, is it 2012 now that we get there? Don't really know. But a combination of that top line as well as continued share repurchase, of course, aids significantly. The margin contribution to that plan is very important, too. We continue to see progression on our annualized margins. And I think that we will ultimately get to those goals that we established. But again, it's going to be a function of capacity utilization to get there. So don't know exactly when it will happen. Is it going to be 2012? Don't know for sure. One other thing that becomes very important is the product proliferation as we develop new products either that take the place of existing products. We need to do so with a mindset to improve our margins in the process. And then also, like we've spoken before, the implementation of brand new products, new to Leggett, with margins that are above average will certainly assist in that pursuit. Again, disappointed that we haven't seen a little more aggressive progression, but it's primarily top line oriented. And we're waiting for that to improve significantly more than it already has.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: You did spend about $4 million in the fourth quarter on acquisitions. I know that's a very small amount. I'm curious, you talked about some more aggressive acquisitions this year. Can you just talk about what you did in the fourth quarter and what you may
componenttext: You did spend about $4 million in the fourth quarter on acquisitions. I know that's a very small amount. I'm curious, you talked about some more aggressive acquisitions this year. Can you just talk about what you did in the fourth quarter and what you may see on the plate?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll let Karl or Matt or Dave talk about what we did in the quarter, and then I'll talk a little bit more about going forward.
componenttext: Yes, I'll let Karl or Matt or Dave talk about what we did in the quarter, and then I'll talk a little bit more about going forward.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Really, Budd, what that was is we bought out the remainder of one of our joint venture partners in the automotive supply business in one of the Asian operations. So we had owned 80% of that firm and bought the remainder.
componenttext: Really, Budd, what that was is we bought out the remainder of one of our joint venture partners in the automotive supply business in one of the Asian operations. So we had owned 80% of that firm and bought the remainder.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. That was, like I said, small but very strategic in nature. Going forward, Budd, we've decided -- we're never totally satisfied with our performance at any point. But we decided that we should really now enter the growth phase of our overall strategy
componenttext: Yes. That was, like I said, small but very strategic in nature. Going forward, Budd, we've decided -- we're never totally satisfied with our performance at any point. But we decided that we should really now enter the growth phase of our overall strategy plan. And as you know, part of that growth phase has to do with getting back into the acquisition saddle but in a way that we're very comfortable with. So in conjunction with the M&A department, Karl, Matt, Dave and the various segment heads, we've established acquisition criteria for each one of the segments and indeed the business groups. Those criteria have been submitted to an outside agency that will assist us in finding fits for those types of potential acquisitions. And so we're starting to see a little acquisition destiny here, and that's a good thing for us.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Rupe with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Rupe with Longbow Research.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is actually Andy in for Mark. Just a quick follow up to Budd's question on CapEx. Do you view that sort of, that roughly $85 million target as sort of sustainable going forward? Do expect to see any further acceleration beyond 2011? How do you think
componenttext: This is actually Andy in for Mark. Just a quick follow up to Budd's question on CapEx. Do you view that sort of, that roughly $85 million target as sort of sustainable going forward? Do expect to see any further acceleration beyond 2011? How do you think about that?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Andy, the way that we look at that and Dave's reminder is valid in that when we started 2010, we forecasted capital spending of $80 million and underspend it. So we're just trying to give ourselves a little bit of running room. It's difficult to plan, spe
componenttext: Andy, the way that we look at that and Dave's reminder is valid in that when we started 2010, we forecasted capital spending of $80 million and underspend it. So we're just trying to give ourselves a little bit of running room. It's difficult to plan, specially on the maintenance side of things. But in terms of the next few years that that $85 million is probably a good number because of the existing capacity that we have in our operations. As we said in the conference call script that we believe we can pass through about $4 billion of demand with the capital that we have in place all the while continuing, obviously, to maintain the mechanical and the structural side of our investments. So absent a significant increase in demand, that's a good plan, might range up to $100 million as we move into the $3.8 billion of sales but who knows?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's the point I was going to make, Karl, is I really can't wait to justify spending more than that because that will require additional production capacity.
componenttext: Yes, that's the point I was going to make, Karl, is I really can't wait to justify spending more than that because that will require additional production capacity.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then on your office furniture side, could you give us a sense of how demand directed the quarter? Did you see any deceleration in the year-over-year trend as you got further into the quarter or was it pretty consistent? What do you see there?
componenttext: And then on your office furniture side, could you give us a sense of how demand directed the quarter? Did you see any deceleration in the year-over-year trend as you got further into the quarter or was it pretty consistent? What do you see there?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Andy, it was very, very consistent that office for the last three quarters has been really strong. And while I went through that explanation about difficult comps in first Q, I will quickly admit that the first Q comp in office is relatively easy and that
componenttext: Andy, it was very, very consistent that office for the last three quarters has been really strong. And while I went through that explanation about difficult comps in first Q, I will quickly admit that the first Q comp in office is relatively easy and that strength was really back half or back three quarters oriented [ph]. But it was strong, is strong and we don't see any slowdown.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And in the bedding, maybe just give us sort of broad strokes in your outlook in 2011 in terms of maybe units and dollars?
componenttext: And in the bedding, maybe just give us sort of broad strokes in your outlook in 2011 in terms of maybe units and dollars?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: We would expect units in that 3% to 4% range slightly over GDP as we start the recovery. And I would say that that expectation holds true for most of our home furnishings businesses. We expect near-term demand because of an element of pent-up demand, and
componenttext: We would expect units in that 3% to 4% range slightly over GDP as we start the recovery. And I would say that that expectation holds true for most of our home furnishings businesses. We expect near-term demand because of an element of pent-up demand, and we think that's relatively conservative, the 3% to 4%. It's very highly correlated to consumer confidence.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from Keith Hughes with SunTrust.

componenttext: Keith, this is Matt. We're assuming it is flat for the year, that there won't be any movement up or down. Obviously, we know that will be wrong but for purposes of our guidance, we assume that it would be, when it's all said and done, flat year in terms of LIFO.

componenttext: That would be a good prediction, just as we sit here today. But in essence, to answer your question, is for the full year we assume it is no impact when it's all said and done.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And, Karl, I just want to clarify your comments on some of the bedding demand. You have talked about being flat in the fourth quarter up until the end of the quarter, I believe, or could you just explain that again?
componenttext: And, Karl, I just want to clarify your comments on some of the bedding demand. You have talked about being flat in the fourth quarter up until the end of the quarter, I believe, or could you just explain that again?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I know I went through a pretty quick detail, I apologize. Know that we actually saw that we were flat in December. So the quarter, as it progressed, the demand, it's hard for me to say good, became less bad. So October was down in that 6% range, and
componenttext: Yes, I know I went through a pretty quick detail, I apologize. Know that we actually saw that we were flat in December. So the quarter, as it progressed, the demand, it's hard for me to say good, became less bad. So October was down in that 6% range, and this is innerspring units. November, we saw some softness and that was actually reflected in the published ISPA data for that month. Then we saw about 8% reduction. December itself was flat bringing the quarter innerspring units to negative five. While box springs were flat through the quarter.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then you said January started off flat, and then you had a tough week a week ago with the weather, correct?
componenttext: And then you said January started off flat, and then you had a tough week a week ago with the weather, correct?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Exactly right.
componenttext: Exactly right.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And if you look at the ISPA numbers for the quarter, it's up a couple of points in units. Is the difference between your results and that what's going on at the very low end of the mattress market?
componenttext: And if you look at the ISPA numbers for the quarter, it's up a couple of points in units. Is the difference between your results and that what's going on at the very low end of the mattress market?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I would say that the real difference is that our box spring numbers I said for the fourth quarter were flat. I believe that the market was flat. The whole market was flat in the fourth quarter on bedding demand. Remember the ISPA statistics just cover
componenttext: No. I would say that the real difference is that our box spring numbers I said for the fourth quarter were flat. I believe that the market was flat. The whole market was flat in the fourth quarter on bedding demand. Remember the ISPA statistics just cover 64% of the total market and generally, really all the alternative sleep guys and the large conventional players. So we still believe that in this economy, with the big guys trading down, that there was some cannibalization from the big of the smaller customer.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert Kelly with Sidoti & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Kelly with Sidoti & Company.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: As far as the 2011 sales outlook, you talked about the price increases that you're attempting to get. Does that include a couple percent of price, the sales outlook?
componenttext: As far as the 2011 sales outlook, you talked about the price increases that you're attempting to get. Does that include a couple percent of price, the sales outlook?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Rob, no. That sales increase, call it 4% of the midpoint roughly, we expect that to be units. There will be inflation on top of that. We don't know as we sit here today what the back half will bring in terms of inflation deflation. Most of the inflation i
componenttext: Rob, no. That sales increase, call it 4% of the midpoint roughly, we expect that to be units. There will be inflation on top of that. We don't know as we sit here today what the back half will bring in terms of inflation deflation. Most of the inflation is being driven by cost of steel, of steel-related items. So we left ourselves kind of some running room. So inflation should layer on top of that. And I'll just remind you, I know you notice that we won't have the same contribution margin on those incremental sales as we would on the unit driven sales. That's the core of our sales guidance.

componenttextpreview: Joel, this is Matt. I'll just add one other because it's a hot topic that lasted several questions, and that is if you think about our incremental margin, which we used as a primary reference, which is 30% for each $100 million increase in sales unit driv
componenttext: Joel, this is Matt. I'll just add one other because it's a hot topic that lasted several questions, and that is if you think about our incremental margin, which we used as a primary reference, which is 30% for each $100 million increase in sales unit driven, mind you, that should bring about $30 million give or take in EBIT. And if you do the math, at an EPS, that is adding between $0.12 or $0.13 per share, not bearing in mind share contraction if that continues to take place, and product mix, assumes that's basically where it is right now. So the gearing on every $100 million increase in sales should be, all things else being relatively stable, somewhere in that 12% to 13% range. I would also quickly add, I know Dave and Karl would as well, in some of our businesses our incremental margin would be better than 30%, and some wouldn't be quite as good as 30%. But again, as a rule of thumb for many of you asking that sort of question, that might be helpful.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Herb, there are difficult conversations but we have been very consistent in the methodology that we implement price increases over the years. Our customers do a good job of understanding the indexes. We had warned most of our steel-related customers 60 da
componenttext: Herb, there are difficult conversations but we have been very consistent in the methodology that we implement price increases over the years. Our customers do a good job of understanding the indexes. We had warned most of our steel-related customers 60 days before the announcement of the increase. The increase usually goes into place 30 to 45 days from the date of announcement. So I don't want to characterize the conversations as easy, but they're certainly clearly understood by our customer base. Our position in the market has been a long one. We've been consistent and fair in our dealings. So they weren't traumatic. I will say, at the Las Vegas furniture market last week, a lot of those conversations face-to-face with customers. And they clearly understood, I'm not going to say they were appreciative, but they clearly understood our position. And they generally are optimistic enough about demand going forward that it truly was not a significant issue.

componenttext: Yes, this is Karl again. We believe that 14% to 15% range is what you as investors should hold us accountable for. If it is challenged in a very quick highly inflationary environment to stay at that level but we've invested a lot of money and time and effort in systems that will allow us to keep it, that relatively low working capital level. And that's what we hold ourselves accountable for. I'm not going to say it won't spike at quarters, but over a long haul that 14% to 15% range is what we should look.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Greetings and welcome to the Leggett & Platt Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, David DeSonier, Vice President, Strategy and Investor Relations for Leggett & Platt. Thank you, Mr. DeSonier
componenttext:
Greetings and welcome to the Leggett & Platt Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, David DeSonier, Vice President, Strategy and Investor Relations for Leggett & Platt. 
Thank you, Mr. DeSonier, you may begin.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for taking part in Leggett & Platt's fourth quarter conference call. I'm Dave DeSonier. And with me today are the following: Dave Haffner, our CEO and President; Karl Glassman, our Chief Operating Officer; Matt Flanigan, our CF
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for taking part in Leggett & Platt's fourth quarter conference call. I'm Dave DeSonier. And with me today are the following: Dave Haffner, our CEO and President; Karl Glassman, our Chief Operating Officer; Matt Flanigan, our CFO; and Susan McCoy, our Director of Investor Relations. The agenda for the call this morning is as follows: Dave Haffner will start with the summary of the major statements we made in yesterday's press release; Karl will provide operating highlights; Dave will then address our outlook for 2011; and finally, the group will answer any questions you have.
I'll mention to you that during the Q&A, Dave Haffner will direct the questions. We're all located in different sites today due to the weather. We have about 20 inches of snow and many of us are still at home trying to dig out of our neighborhood. 
This conference is being recorded for Leggett & Platt and is a copyrighted material. This call may not be transcribed, recorded or broadcast without our express permission. A replay is available from the IR portion of Leggett's website. 
We posted to the IR portion of the website a set of PowerPoint slides that contain summary financial information. Those slides supplement the information we discuss on this call, including non-GAAP reconciliations. I need to remind you that remarks today concerning future expectations, events, objectives, strategies, trends or results constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results or events may differ materially due to a number of risks and uncertainties, and the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise these statements. For a summary of these risk factors and additional information, please refer to yesterday's press release and the section in our 10-K entitled forward-looking statements. 
I'll now turn the call over to Dave Haffner.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning from sunny Missouri, and thank you for participating in our call. Yesterday, we reported fourth quarter and full year results.For the quarter, sales increased 4% compared to the prior year primarily reflecting growth in unit volumes in the
componenttext:
Good morning from sunny Missouri, and thank you for participating in our call. Yesterday, we reported fourth quarter and full year results.
For the quarter, sales increased 4% compared to the prior year primarily reflecting growth in unit volumes in the Specialized Products and Industrial Materials segments. Earnings per share for the quarter were $0.21 versus $0.26 for the same quarter last year. The earnings benefit from higher unit volumes and a lower effective tax rate were offset by a net change in LIFO impact and higher raw material costs.
In the fourth quarter of 2009, we recognized a LIFO benefit of $15 million. As anticipated, that benefit did not recur this year. Instead, in the fourth quarter of 2010, we incurred LIFO expense of $5 million for a year-over-year net change of $20 million.
In late 2010, steel costs began increasing again. These increases along with higher than anticipated LIFO expense led to 150 to 200 basis points of margin compression in the fourth quarter. We have announced price increases in our major steel consuming businesses to recover the higher costs. These increases vary in magnitude depending upon the product category and are being implemented during the first quarter of 2011.
Because of the lag in cost recovery, our first quarter margins will likely be under pressure, but we expect margins to normalize by the second quarter. 
For the full year 2010, we're pleased with the improvements we posted. In both sales and earnings per share, we achieved full year results at or above the high end of guidance issued at the start of the year. Sales grew 10% to $3.36 billion. 
Demand improved in many of our markets during the year. The automotive and office furniture markets experienced significant growth from very depressed demand levels in 2009. Retail fixturing demand was also reasonably strong. Our residential bedding and furniture markets started 2010 strong but weakened in the last half of the year as consumer spending on larger ticket items slowed.
Activities completed over the past few years including the divestiture of businesses under our strategic plan, closure of certain underperforming and underutilized facilities, elimination of sales with unacceptable margins and other cost reduction initiatives improved our cost position and enabled earnings to benefit notably from the higher volume. 
Full year earnings increased to $1.15 per share, which is a 64% improvement versus the $0.70 per share reported in 2009.
During 2010, we completed the sale of the seventh and final divestiture identified as a part of our strategic realignment. The seven divestitures collectively generated $433 million of after-tax cash proceeds over the past three years, exceeding their original $400 million goal. 
Our focus on optimizing returns was reflected throughout 2010 in part through the low level of working capital that was maintained as sales began to recover. We ended the year with working capital at 14.1% of annualized sales.
For the year, we generated operating cash of $363 million, which significantly exceeded the $223 million required to fund capital expenditures and dividends. 
In August, we raised the quarterly dividend to $0.27 per share and extended to 39 years our record of consecutive annual dividend increases. At yesterday's closing price of $22.96, the current dividend yield is 4.7%. As planned, much of the excess operating cash was used to repurchase 6.2 million shares of our stock during 2010.
Our financial profile remains strong. We ended 2010 with net debt to net capital at 23.3%, well below our long-term targeted range of 30% to 40%, no significant fixed term debt maturing until 2013 and over $500 million available under our existing bank facility. We continue to assess our overall performance by comparing our Total Shareholder Return on a rolling three-year basis to that of peer companies. We target TSR in the top 1/3 of the S&P 500 over the long term, which we believe will require an average TSR of 12% to 15% per year. For the three years ended December 31 of 2010, we generated TSR of 16% per year on average, which ranks among the top 8% of the companies in the S&P 500 Index.
And with those comments, I'll turn the call over to Karl Glassman, who will provide some operating highlights. Karl?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave. Good morning. In my comments, I will discuss a few segment highlights. You will find segment details on yesterday's press release and in the slide presentation on our website. As Dave mentioned, our residential bedding and furniture marke
componenttext:
Thank you, Dave. Good morning. In my comments, I will discuss a few segment highlights. You will find segment details on yesterday's press release and in the slide presentation on our website. As Dave mentioned, our residential bedding and furniture markets started 2010 strong but weakened in the last half of the year as consumer spending on larger ticket items slowed.
Fourth quarter sales in the Residential Furnishings segment decreased slightly versus the prior year. Steel-related price inflation from price increases implemented earlier in 2010 was more than offset by unit volume declines in several key businesses.
In our U.S. spring business, innerspring unit volumes decreased 5% in the fourth quarter and box spring units were flat. Unit volumes also declined versus the prior year in our international spring, fabric converting and carpet underlay businesses. 
In our furniture hardware business, the unit volume increased slightly in the fourth quarter. The majority of the full year revenue growth that we experienced in the Residential Furnishings segment is attributable to our furniture components business. This growth is primarily due to market share gains, a well-established international presence and ongoing strength in motion upholstery as consumers continue to favor seating with added functionality and comfort.
Lower unit volumes and higher raw material costs led to a decrease in the segment's fourth quarter EBIT and EBIT margins versus the prior year. We have recently announced price increases in our major steel consuming businesses, including bedding and furniture components, to recover the higher raw material cost. The selling price increases vary by product line ranging from approximately 8% in bedding components to 12% in furniture hardware. We have also announced price increases in our fabric converting and carpet underlay businesses to recover recent inflation in the cost of fabrics and foam scrap. All of the announced selling price increases will be implemented during the first quarter of 2011. 
Current demand in our residential end markets remains well below historical levels. This presents a notable opportunity for both sales and earnings growth over the next few years as those markets recover.
We believe our residential end markets have stabilized and while recovery may continue to be choppy, we are expecting modest overall demand improvements in these markets during 2011.
In the Commercial Fixturing & Components segment, fourth quarter sales grew slightly. We continue to see convincing signs of improvement in the office furniture industry. Fourth quarter sales in our office components business grew approximately 20%, reflecting both market recovery and new programs that we have been awarded. This was the third consecutive quarter that we experienced strong growth in this business.
Sales in our fixture and display business decreased approximately 10% during the fourth quarter versus fourth quarter of 2009. Our prior year comps were difficult due to a high level of late year activity in 2009 by some of our large customers.
For the full year 2010, sales in our store fixtures  and display business grew approximately 5%. Seasonality of this business changed in 2010, with  volume in the first three quarters of the year roughly proportional as retailers increased remodeling activity and reduced new store construction. We expect similar seasonality in 2011. 
EBIT and EBIT margins in the Commercial Fixturing & Components segment decreased versus fourth quarter of 2009. The benefit from sales growth in office components was offset by restructuring-related costs associated with the closure of a wood store fixtures operation. 
Fourth quarter sales in our Industrial Materials segment increased 8%. Growth from higher unit volumes and steel-related price inflation was partially offset by a small divestiture. EBIT and EBIT margins decreased versus fourth quarter of 2009 as higher unit volumes were offset by the absence of EBIT associated with a small divestiture and lower metal margins in the steel industry that reduced the profitability of our steel rod mill. Price increases have recently been announced and implemented in our rod and wire drawing operations in response to the escalation in steel scrap cost. 
In the Specialized Products segment, we posted 17% sales growth in the fourth quarter from continued strength in global automotive demand. We also experienced sales growth in commercial vehicle products during the quarter. Automotive industry forecasts continue to anticipate meaningful global production growth in 2011.
With those comments, I'll turn the call back over to Dave.

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karl. Over the last three years, we significantly reduced our fixed cost structure but have retained spare production capacity so that we can accommodate additional sales without the need for large capital investments. As a result, we have mean
componenttext:
Thank you, Karl. Over the last three years, we significantly reduced our fixed cost structure but have retained spare production capacity so that we can accommodate additional sales without the need for large capital investments. As a result, we have meaningful operating leverage that should benefit earnings as sales increase. 
For 2011, we expect sales of approximately $3.4 billion to $3.6 billion, reflecting our belief that the economy will continue to improve modestly. Based on this sales expectation and considering other uncertainties including inflation and steel costs, we project 2011 earnings to be between $1.20 and $1.40 per share.
Cash from operations should exceed $300 million again in 2011. Capital expenditures are expected to be about $85 million, and dividend payments should approximate $155 million.
For the full year, we anticipate purchasing up to 10 million shares of our stock and issuing approximately 3 million shares. We have a standing authorization from the board to repurchase up to 10 million shares each year, but we have no specific repurchase commitment or timetable associated with that authorization.
While challenges continue in certain areas of our business, we are addressing those. We are pleased with many of the business units and their continued progress. We would like to extend our sincere appreciation to our customers for their ongoing support. We remain committed to working together with you for our mutual long-term prosperity. We would also like to thank our employee partners, the men and women whose hard work has contributed to the past year's progress and helped position Leggett for long-term success.
And with those comments, I'll turn the call back over to Dave DeSonier. Dave?

headline: Leggett & Platt, Incorporated, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: That concludes our prepared remarks. We thank you for your attention and we will be glad to answer your questions. In order to allow everyone an opportunity to participate, we request that you ask your single best question and then voluntarily yield  to t
componenttext:
That concludes our prepared remarks. We thank you for your attention and we will be glad to answer your questions. In order to allow everyone an opportunity to participate, we request that you ask your single best question and then voluntarily yield  to the next participant. If you additional questions, please re-enter the queue and we'll answer all the questions you have. 
Diego, we are ready to begin the Q&A.
